subject: Track and Field
Clay
lead_paragraph: Tyson Gay sliced through a headwind for a 9.84-second clocking last night in Indianapolis in the most one-sided 100-meter victory at the U.S. track and field championships since electronic timing began 32 years ago.Gay broke the meet record in the second-fastest 100 ever run into a headwind. The only one faster was Maurice Greene’s 9.82 at the 2001 world championships. Gay ran into a wind of 1.12 m.p.h., Greene’s was 0.45 m.p.h. Gay’s time was easily the world’s fastest this year.
